The present discussion has attempted to illustrate the analytical leverage gained by drawing on both game-theoretical and microsociological resources in addressing these questions, and, more generally, by seeking a broader conceptual and empirical footing for future work on the microfoundations of sociological inquiry.

fn.p: ‘Garfinkel simply fails to generate any insights at all from the approach. (…) Perhaps the program would be more fertile in the hands of someone more carefully observant or more analytically powerful (…).’ (Coleman, 1968: 126)

Arguably, the payoffs in the latter case of the mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium will be lower than in the case of the pure-strategy coordination equilibria, and both players will be better off coordinating their moves in a ‘battle of the sexes’ scenario than by acting out on a calculation of the most rational variation of moves (Gintis, 2009b: 46–48). There is no space here to discuss the recently much disputed viability of mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium.
In the textbook case of the stag hunt game, payoffs for hunting hare are usually given as equal (d = e = g = h > 0).

The stag hunt matrix, placed in a more contemporary context, can also be considered as describing a work-shirk game with working standing in for the stag solution and shirking for the hare equilibrium. The problem of a potentially risk-dominant choice of equilibrium, that is, of participants settling on shirking rather than working, is, of course, identical (Young, 1998: 17–19).

In the stag hunt game the set of equalities defining the pure coordination game need to be slightly adjusted to a > c, b > d, b > f, g > c, g ≥ e, h ≥ d, h > f in order to make both equilibria rewarding in this sense. In most representations of the stag hunt g = e and h = d. Setting g and h higher than e and d, respectively, would give coordinating to hunt hare the edge of a strict (rather than a weak) Nash equilibrium. This could be justified by an additional utility gained from coordination, for example the greater effectiveness of hunting together even if the prey is smaller.
The etiquette game described by Young (1998: 25–26) provides an example of a battle of the sexes scenario with complementary moves constituting equilibrium points.

Goffman’s respective comments may easily be read as referring to participants and populations learning to effectively coordinate expectations: ‘How a given set of such understandings comes into being historically, spreads and contracts in geographical distribution over time, and how at any one place and time particular individuals acquire these understandings are good questions, but not ones I can address.’ (Goffman, 1983: 5) The present paper can also do little more than indicate the existence of a respective processes, but the issue is clearly associated with an impressive amount of contemporary game-theoretical research (cf. Fudenberg and Levine, 1998), some of which is directly pertinent to the types of games discussed in this paper (e.g. Skyrms, 1996; Sugden, 2004; Young, 1998).
Collins refers to March and Simon (1958) and their analysis of bounded rationality without further elaborating this association.
The classical example is the extension of scientific theories to embody discrepant data (Duhem, 1954: 180–218).

Compare also the analysis by Harsanyi and Selten (1988: 355–357) of the difference between payoff dominance and risk dominance as a correlate of the difference between collective and individual rationality.
Formally organized coordination is a case in point, as Stinchcombe (2001: 61) observes: ‘The informal system is the semantics of the formal system, which is why the formal system works.’

Models of framing abound in social theory. Approaches congenial to the present discussion have been developed in the theory of social action by Siegwart Lindenberg (1993) and Hartmut Esser (2009), and in game theory by the late Michael Bacharach (2006: 14–24, 53–57). Although these approaches discuss framing in a manner that tends to pay more attention to psychological correlates (e.g. in terms of cognitive schemata), which are not discussed here, they do not generally contradict the understanding of framing as correlated equilibrium suggested by the present paper. Rather, they indicate how this understanding can further be informed by the psychology of choice (e.g. Tversky and Kahneman, 1981).

I take this to be a more general understanding of background expectations than the understanding in terms of common knowledge, but there is no space here to discuss differences with respect to coordination games and emergent conventions; see Binmore (2008) and Paternotte (2011) for recent contributions.

Swedberg (2001: 313ff.) argues that game-theoretical research in sociology has, since the 1980s, primarily been focusing on topics that are social-dilemma related, and the interest in norms may be considered an expression of this focus.
